articles.title: Jane Goodall’s legacy: three ways she changed science
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 02 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03209-yThe primatologist challenged what it meant to be a scientist.
articles.content:
Jane Goodall, a British primatologist known for her work with chimpanzees, died on Wednesday 1 October, aged 91. She was in California on a speaking tour and died of natural causes, according to the Jane Goodall Institute.

Goodall is best known for her work with chimpanzees in Gombe National Park in Tanzania. She was the first to discover that chimpanzees made and used tools1. She went on to become an advocate for conservation, human rights and animal welfare, including stopping the use of animals in medical research. She established the Jane Goodall Institute, a non-profit wildlife and conservation organization in Washington DC, in 1977.

Here are the ways in which Goodall’s legacy will endure.

Humanizing primates

While studying for her PhD at the University of Cambridge, UK, in the early 1960s, Goodall broke with the scientific convention of using numbers to identify animals, assigning them names instead. She named a male chimp with silver facial hair David Greybeard. This change upset senior scientists at the time, but it is now common practice to use animal names.

“It was criticized as unscientific,” says Mireya Mayor, an anthropologist and primatologist at Florida International University in Miami, “but she proved that science could extend its boundaries without losing rigour.”

Goodall was among the first to show that animals had emotions, empathy and culture, traits that had been reserved for humans, Mayor says. Her research changed how animal studies were conducted, she adds.

Her discoveries in Gombe National Park “redefined humanity”, says Nick Boyle, executive director of Taronga Zoo in Sydney, Australia. Goodall challenged the idea that chimpanzees were herbivores, and showed that they ate meat, hunted and engaged in warfare, he adds. In 1973, Goodall observed a social divide between two chimpanzee communities that led to a four-year conflict and the deaths of all of the male apes in one of the communities.

Inspiring women scientists

Beyond primatology, Goodall’s legacy is the generations of women she inspired to follow in her footsteps into fieldwork, says Mayor. In 1961, Goodall was one of the few students accepted into a PhD at Cambridge without an undergraduate degree. She completed her PhD in 1965.

“She showed that a young woman with no formal scientific training could rewrite science and the understanding of animals on such a fundamental level,” adds Mayor.

Alison Behie, an anthropologist at the Australian National University, was one of the women Goodall inspired. After attending a talk by Goodall, Behie says she switched her undergraduate major from microbiology to anthropology and started taking primatology and conservation courses. “It was just a happy coincidence, but she came to speak at the exact time that I was not quite sure what sort of science I wanted to do,” she says.

In 2017, Behie introduced eight of her female students to Goodall during her visit to Australia. “It was a full circle for me to be able to show my own students what had inspired me to go down this path.”

Communicating science
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Jane Goodall's pioneering scientific contributions and her lasting legacy in conservation, animal welfare, and inspiring women in science, which has broad societal impact and promotes human rights and ethical treatment of animals.
articles.personality_title: Jane Goodall’s lasting impact on science and conservation
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Jane Goodall was a British scientist who studied chimpanzees in Tanzania. She became famous for discovering that chimpanzees use tools, a skill once thought to be unique to humans. She worked for many years to protect animals and the environment.

**What happened** – Jane Goodall died on October 1, 2025, at the age of 91 while on a speaking tour in California. She founded the Jane Goodall Institute in 1977 to support wildlife conservation and animal welfare. She also changed how scientists study animals by giving them names instead of numbers and showing that animals have feelings and cultures.

**Impact** – Goodall’s work changed science by proving that animals are more like humans than people believed. She showed chimpanzees hunt and fight, which was surprising at the time. She inspired many women to become scientists and helped make animal protection a global cause. Her ideas still influence how we understand animals and nature today.

**What's next step** – The Jane Goodall Institute will continue her work protecting chimpanzees and their habitats. More scientists will build on her discoveries to learn about animals’ emotions and social lives. Her example encourages new generations, especially women, to enter science and conservation.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Jane Goodall transformed how we study and care for animals, inspiring science and conservation for decades to come.

articles.content:
Click to expand Image The Reparations Task Force meets to hear public input on reparations at the California Science Center in Los Angeles, US, September 22, 2022. © 2022 Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times via Getty Images

Volker Türk, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, stressed the need and urgency forcomprehensive reparatory justice for historical and ongoing harm linked to colonialism and enslavementon October 1 at the United Nations Human Rights Council (UNHRC) in Geneva. The report is timely as attacks on even minimal diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts mount in the United States and elsewhere.

In an oral statement delivered at the UNHRC session, Human Rights Watch expressed support for his call for a transformative, context-specific, and rights-based approach to reparatory justice, led by the most affected communities.

Whether addressing the US’ legacy of enslavement or European legacies of enslavement and colonialism, Türk stressed that affected communities should drive the design and outcome of reparatory processes. He also said that private institutions, such as museums, corporations, universities, and religious groupsshould take responsibility for their historical benefits, ties, and roles in perpetuating the abuses of colonialism and enslavement.

He called for broad systemic reforms, such as addressing environmental injustices that disproportionately impact Africans and people of African descent as well as international financial systems that contribute toracial inequalities. This is particularly relevant as discussions about reparations around the world gain momentum.

In the US, some states and localities are exploring or already implementing reparative measures despite backsliding at the national level. African and Caribbean countries are working to join their agendas to strengthen their pursuit for reparatory justice by European and other governments, including at the recent Africa-CARICOM summit. The African Union and UN have dedicated the next decade to reparatory justice.

Echoed by African states who spoke at the UNHRC session in Geneva, the UN rights chief’s call to action challenges governments and institutions to reckon with their legacies and move beyond symbolic gestures.

In the US, this means Congress should adopt H.R. 40, which calls for creating an expert commission to study and develop reparation proposals to address the lasting impacts of enslavement and subsequent racial injustices for African Americans. For Europe, it means that governments should accept legal responsibility to address their enslavement and colonial legacies.

Achieving reparatory justice is not only a moral imperative but a right, with associated legal obligations,and a necessary step toward creating equitable societies rooted in acknowledgement, reconciliation, and justice.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant and timely call by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights for comprehensive reparatory justice addressing historical and ongoing harms from colonialism and enslavement. It highlights broad international efforts, including governmental and institutional accountability, systemic reforms, and active reparations measures in various regions. The story has broad societal impact by promoting equity, justice, and reconciliation for affected communities worldwide, supported by detailed context and concrete actions.
articles.personality_title: UN calls for justice and reparations for harms from colonialism and enslavement
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many countries and communities are dealing with the lasting effects of colonialism and slavery. These histories have caused harm that continues today, affecting people’s lives and opportunities.

**What happened** – On October 1, Volker Türk, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, spoke at the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva. He urged governments and institutions to take strong action to provide reparations—meaning fair compensation and justice—to those harmed by colonialism and enslavement. He said the communities most affected should lead these efforts. He also called on museums, companies, schools, and churches to accept responsibility for their roles in these histories.

**Impact** – This call is important because it pushes for real changes, not just words. It highlights the need to fix unfair systems, like environmental damage and financial rules that hurt people of African descent. Some U.S. states and countries in Africa and the Caribbean are already working on reparations. The UN and the African Union plan to focus on this for the next ten years, showing a strong global commitment.

**What's next step** – In the U.S., there is a law called H.R. 40 that would create a group to study reparations and suggest ways to make them happen. The UN wants Congress to pass it. European governments are also encouraged to accept responsibility and act. These steps could lead to new laws and programs that help heal communities and build fairer societies.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The United Nations is urging countries and institutions to take real responsibility and provide reparations to repair the lasting harms caused by colonialism and enslavement.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’ONU appelle à la justice et aux réparations pour les dommages causés par le colonialisme et l’esclavage
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – De nombreux pays et communautés subissent encore les effets durables du colonialisme et de l’esclavage. Ces histoires ont causé des souffrances qui continuent aujourd’hui, affectant la vie et les chances des personnes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 1er octobre, Volker Türk, Haut-Commissaire des Nations Unies aux droits de l’homme, a pris la parole au Conseil des droits de l’homme des Nations Unies à Genève. Il a demandé aux gouvernements et aux institutions d’agir fortement pour offrir des réparations — c’est-à-dire une compensation juste et la justice — aux personnes victimes du colonialisme et de l’esclavage. Il a souligné que les communautés les plus touchées doivent diriger ces efforts. Il a aussi appelé les musées, entreprises, universités et églises à reconnaître leur rôle dans ces histoires.

**Impact** – Cet appel est important car il pousse à des changements concrets, pas seulement des paroles. Il souligne la nécessité de corriger des systèmes injustes, comme les dommages environnementaux et les règles financières qui nuisent aux personnes d’ascendance africaine. Certains États américains et des pays d’Afrique et des Caraïbes travaillent déjà sur des réparations. L’ONU et l’Union africaine prévoient de se concentrer sur ce sujet pendant les dix prochaines années, montrant un engagement mondial fort.

**Prochaine étape** – Aux États-Unis, une loi appelée H.R. 40 propose de créer un groupe pour étudier les réparations et suggérer des moyens de les réaliser. L’ONU souhaite que le Congrès l’adopte. Les gouvernements européens sont aussi encouragés à reconnaître leurs responsabilités et à agir. Ces mesures pourraient mener à de nouvelles lois et programmes pour aider à guérir les communautés et construire des sociétés plus justes.

**Phrase clé** – L’ONU encourage les pays et institutions à prendre leurs responsabilités et à offrir des réparations pour réparer les dommages durables causés par le colonialisme et l’esclavage.
articles.personality_title_es: La ONU pide justicia y reparaciones por los daños del colonialismo y la esclavitud
articles.personality_presentation_es:

**Qué pasó** – El 1 de octubre, Volker Türk, Alto Comisionado de las Naciones Unidas para los Derechos Humanos, habló en el Consejo de Derechos Humanos de la ONU en Ginebra. Instó a gobiernos e instituciones a tomar medidas firmes para ofrecer reparaciones — es decir, compensación justa y justicia — a quienes han sufrido por el colonialismo y la esclavitud. Dijo que las comunidades más afectadas deben liderar estos esfuerzos. También pidió a museos, empresas, universidades y grupos religiosos que acepten su responsabilidad en estas historias.

**Impacto** – Esta llamada es importante porque impulsa cambios reales, no solo palabras. articles.title: Loneliness as a ‘silent pandemic’ in the EU: Project aims to develop solutions
articles.summary: Is the loneliness of people also a political problem? From the experts' perspective, yes. In Brussels, scientists and politicians met to discuss the effects of loneliness on democracy and societies in the EU and to jointly seek solutions.
articles.content:
Is the loneliness of people also a political problem? From the experts’ perspective, yes. In Brussels, scientists and politicians met to discuss the effects of loneliness on democracy and societies in the EU and to jointly seek solutions.

Brussels (enr) – When people often feel lonely, it can have negative effects on society as well. The fight against loneliness must therefore be prioritized more strongly within the EU, experts and politicians demanded at the “Loneliness Forum,” which the state government of North Rhine-Westphalia hosted on Wednesday at its EU representation in Brussels.

The research project “The Social Isolation and Loneliness in Europe Network: Evidence-Based Policy Recommendations on its Causes, Consequences, and Monitoring” (LONELY-EU) was presented, which has been running since February 2025 and is funded by the EU with around three million euros.

Maike Luhmann, a psychology professor at Ruhr University Bochum, summarized the negative consequences of loneliness for individuals and the community. People who feel lonely are more often sick, less productive, and less creative, which means they contribute less to economic performance. At the same time, lonely individuals have a stronger tendency to radicalize politically or completely withdraw from participation in democracy.

The research on this topic is still quite young, Luhmann said. The LONELY-EU project therefore aims to establish a Europe-wide network of people and organizations that deal with the issue of loneliness and want to develop solutions together. So far, researchers from Poland, the Netherlands, Italy, France, and Germany are involved. Among other things, they want to measure loneliness more effectively: “We need more data and want to better understand existing data,” said Prof. Luhmann.

Luhmann referred to survey results from 2022 and 2024 regarding the prevalence of loneliness within the EU. According to this, 13 percent of people feel lonely always or most of the time, and 35 percent at least sometimes. At the same time, there are regional differences: In Ireland, for example, loneliness is more widespread than in Spain or the Netherlands.

The Minister-President of North Rhine-Westphalia, Hendrik Wüst, explained why he sees his state as a pioneer in combating loneliness and has made the issue a top priority. He took office during the Corona pandemic, Wüst said, and by the end of it, it was clear that loneliness itself was a “silent pandemic.” Wüst described the fight against loneliness as “the new social question of our time.” He referred to an action plan in his state, which compiled more than 100 measures across departments, as well as an online platform that summarizes more than 800 actions against loneliness. However, the problem is by no means solved: “We need to be persistent. Therefore, it is all the more important that we start.”

Expert discussion at the “Loneliness Forum” in the NRW representation in Brussels: Panel participants included (l.to r.) Austrian EU Member of Parliament Evelyn Regner (SPÖ), Tim Kramer (founder of the “Vereint Bochum” association), and Prof. Maike Luhmann (Ruhr University Bochum). Also among the audience was NRW Minister-President Hendrik Wüst (CDU). Photo: Christian Röwekamp/enr

The EU Commissioner for intergenerational justice, youth, culture, and sport, Glenn Micallef from Malta, also referred to the societal challenges posed by loneliness. While younger people are often strongly affected, particularly those over 80 suffer greatly from the consequences of their loneliness. Ultimately, the problem affects all age groups. It is therefore important to have as many offerings as possible in culture and sports that bring people together.

The research results and proposals from LONELY-EU are to be presented in November 2027. (October 1)
articles.reasoning: The article describes a significant EU-funded research project addressing loneliness, a widespread social issue with serious health, economic, and democratic participation consequences. It highlights collaborative efforts among multiple countries and policymakers to develop evidence-based solutions, showing meaningful societal impact and broad relevance across Europe.
articles.personality_title: EU project tackles loneliness to improve health and democracy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Loneliness is more than just a feeling; it can affect how societies and democracies work. Experts in the European Union (EU) see loneliness as a growing problem that needs attention.

**What happened** – In Brussels, scientists and politicians met at the "Loneliness Forum" to discuss loneliness and its effects. They introduced the LONELY-EU project, which started in February 2025. This project is funded by the EU with about three million euros and includes researchers from countries like Poland, the Netherlands, Italy, France, and Germany. They aim to better understand loneliness by collecting data and finding solutions.

**Impact** – Loneliness can make people sick, less creative, and less active in their communities. It can also lead some to withdraw from democracy or even become politically extreme. Around 13% of people in the EU feel lonely most of the time, and 35% feel lonely sometimes. Some countries, like Ireland, have higher rates than others, like Spain or the Netherlands. The project is important because it brings together many countries to work on a problem that affects health, the economy, and how societies function.

**What's next step** – The LONELY-EU team plans to keep collecting data and develop recommendations. They will share their research and ideas in November 2027. Meanwhile, places like North Rhine-Westphalia in Germany are already trying many ways to help lonely people, such as creating online platforms and action plans with hundreds of ideas.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s LONELY-EU project is bringing countries together to better understand and fight loneliness, aiming to improve health and democratic participation across Europe.

articles.title: Strategic cooperation between Greece and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office to enhance transparency and protect European resources
articles.summary: Meeting with the European Chief Prosecutor Laura Kövesi was held at the offices of the Independent Authority for Public Revenue, attended by the Minister of National Economy and Finance Kyriakos Pierrakakis, Deputy Minister George Kotsiras, and the Deputy Governor of the Independent Authority for Public Revenue George Pitsilis.
articles.content:
Meeting with the European Chief Prosecutor Laura Kövesi was held at the offices of the Independent Authority for Public Revenue, attended by the Minister of National Economy and Finance Kyriakos Pierrakakis, Deputy Minister George Kotsiras, and the Deputy Governor of the Independent Authority for Public Revenue George Pitsilis.

Meeting with the European Chief Prosecutor Laura Kövesi took place at the offices of the Independent Authority for Public Revenue (AADE), attended by the Minister of National Economy and Finance Kyriakos Pierrakakis, Deputy Minister George Kotsiras, and the Deputy Governor of the AADE George Pitsilis.

The meeting also included the head of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) Milan Jaron and the Greek European Prosecutor Nikolaos Paschalis.

The discussion focused on further strengthening the cooperation between Greece and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office for more effective combat against customs and tax fraud. The minister and the head of the AADE presented to the European Chief Prosecutor the comprehensive modernization and strengthening program of the Greek customs, which is being implemented under the name Customs NextGEN.

By 2029, the following are planned:

*Integration of the Financial Crime Unit (SDOE) into the AADE. By October 2025, the General Directorate of SDOE will be fully integrated into the AADE.

*Authorized Economic Operators (AEO). The approach to reliable economic operators for granting AEO status and additional simplifications is underway.

*Customs Document Control Center. Establishment of a Customs Control Center in Thessaloniki for the control of customs documents, incorporating procedures for 40 Customs offices across the country by June 2026.

*Hellenic Digital Customs Borders. By 2026, development of a comprehensive digital monitoring system for trucks, containers, and vehicles entering or exiting the country.

*Container Targeting Center – Piraeus. Creation of a specialized hub for locating suspicious containers at the Port of Piraeus by September 2026, in cooperation with the British authorities HMRC and UK Border Force.

*UCC Reform & Digitization (2026-2029). Comprehensive reform and overall upgrade of the national customs information system, aiming for the full digitization of customs procedures, in accordance with the Union Customs Code (UCC).

Funding for the program:

*80 million euros have already been allocated from the Recovery and Resilience Fund (RRF) for the digital project monitoring trucks and containers at border customs stations.

*In the next four years, an additional 203 million euros will be invested to enhance operational capacity.

Detailed investment distribution (by 2027):

*125 million euros to strengthen Customs with approximately 1,100 employees, in addition to the existing staff, prioritizing the Port of Piraeus and logistics services in Attica.

*40 million euros for the procurement of 8 X-Ray systems for cargo inspections.

*20 million euros for the procurement of 2 X-Ray systems for freight trains.

*18 million euros for the development of a new Customs information system.

In total, more than 280 million euros will be allocated for the funding of Customs NextGEN.

During the discussion, the following issues were also raised:

*Identification and reporting of customs and tax fraud cases (VAT), utilizing advanced risk analysis tools and cross-border data exchange.

*Provision of specialized financial investigators and customs officials to support the investigations of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office in Greece.

*Deployment of national experts to the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, aiming to enhance the interoperability of national systems with EU procedures.

*Access of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office to the EUROFISC information network, which is a key tool for rapid information exchange aimed at preventing and combating VAT fraud.

*Salary equalization for officials for NEDPAs (Secretaries and Financial Investigators) serving in the Athens Office, with the remuneration in line with corresponding auditing services of national authorities, in recognition of the increased workload and their critical contribution to the success of investigations.

According to the ministry, the meeting confirmed the excellent cooperation between Greece and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, while expressing the willingness for further deepening of joint action, for the benefit of transparency and the protection of the Greek and European budget. (01/10/25)

articles.personality_title: Greece teams up with European Public Prosecutor to fight customs and tax fraud
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Greece is working closely with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO) to improve how customs and tax fraud are detected and prevented. This cooperation aims to protect money that belongs to both Greece and the European Union.

**What happened** – On October 1, 2025, a meeting took place at the Independent Authority for Public Revenue (AADE) in Greece. The European Chief Prosecutor Laura Kövesi met with Greek officials, including the Minister of National Economy and Finance, Kyriakos Pierrakakis. They discussed plans to modernize Greek customs through a program called Customs NextGEN. This program includes new technology, better cooperation between agencies, and investments totaling over 280 million euros.

**Impact** – The Customs NextGEN program will bring important changes by 2029. For example, it will create digital systems to monitor trucks and containers crossing borders, set up a center to check suspicious cargo at the Port of Piraeus, and fully integrate the Financial Crime Unit into the customs authority. These changes will make it harder for criminals to commit fraud and will help protect public money more effectively.

**What's next step** – Greece will continue to invest in new technology and staff, including hiring about 1,100 new customs employees. The country will also work on better sharing information with European partners and improving the skills of investigators. By 2026, key parts of the program, like the digital customs borders and control centers, should be operational.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Greece and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office are joining forces with new technology and funding to stop customs and tax fraud and safeguard public funds.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Grèce collabore avec le Bureau du Procureur européen pour lutter contre la fraude douanière et fiscale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Grèce travaille en étroite collaboration avec le Bureau du Procureur européen (EPPO) pour améliorer la détection et la prévention de la fraude douanière et fiscale. Cette coopération vise à protéger les fonds appartenant à la fois à la Grèce et à l’Union européenne.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 1er octobre 2025, une réunion a eu lieu au sein de l’Autorité indépendante pour les recettes publiques (AADE) en Grèce. La Procureure européenne en chef Laura Kövesi a rencontré des responsables grecs, dont le ministre de l’Économie nationale et des Finances, Kyriakos Pierrakakis. Ils ont discuté des plans de modernisation des douanes grecques via un programme nommé Customs NextGEN, qui comprend de nouvelles technologies, une meilleure coopération entre agences et des investissements de plus de 280 millions d’euros.

**Impact** – Le programme Customs NextGEN apportera des changements importants d’ici 2029. Par exemple, il créera des systèmes numériques pour surveiller les camions et conteneurs aux frontières, établira un centre de contrôle des cargaisons suspectes au port du Pirée, et intégrera pleinement l’Unité des crimes financiers à l’autorité douanière. Ces mesures rendront la fraude plus difficile et protégeront mieux les fonds publics.

**Prochaine étape** – La Grèce continuera d’investir dans de nouvelles technologies et du personnel, avec environ 1 100 nouveaux employés des douanes. Le pays améliorera aussi le partage d’informations avec ses partenaires européens et renforcera les compétences des enquêteurs. D’ici 2026, les principales parties du programme, comme les frontières douanières numériques et les centres de contrôle, devraient être opérationnelles.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Grèce et le Bureau du Procureur européen unissent leurs forces avec de nouvelles technologies et financements pour lutter contre la fraude douanière et fiscale et protéger les fonds publics.
articles.personality_title_es: Grecia se une con la Fiscalía Europea para combatir el fraude aduanero y fiscal
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Grecia trabaja estrechamente con la Fiscalía Europea (EPPO) para mejorar la detección y prevención del fraude aduanero y fiscal. Esta cooperación busca proteger el dinero que pertenece tanto a Grecia como a la Unión Europea.

**Qué pasó** – El 1 de octubre de 2025, se realizó una reunión en la Autoridad Independiente de Ingresos Públicos (AADE) en Grecia. La Fiscal Europea Jefa, Laura Kövesi, se reunió con funcionarios griegos, incluido el Ministro de Economía y Finanzas, Kyriakos Pierrakakis. Hablaron sobre planes para modernizar las aduanas griegas mediante un programa llamado Customs NextGEN, que incluye nueva tecnología, mejor cooperación entre agencias e inversiones por más de 280 millones de euros.

**Impacto** – El programa Customs NextGEN traerá cambios importantes para 2029. Por ejemplo, creará sistemas digitales para monitorear camiones y contenedores en las fronteras, establecerá un centro para revisar carga sospechosa en el Puerto de El Pireo e integrará completamente la Unidad de Crímenes Financieros a la autoridad aduanera. Estos cambios harán más difícil la fraude y ayudarán a proteger mejor el dinero público.

**Próximo paso** – Grecia continuará invirtiendo en nueva tecnología y personal, con alrededor de 1,100 nuevos empleados de aduanas. También mejorará el intercambio de información con socios europeos y fortalecerá las habilidades de los investigadores. Para 2026, las partes clave del programa, como las fronteras aduaneras digitales y los centros de control, deberían estar en funcionamiento.

**Resumen en una frase** – Grecia y la Fiscalía Europea unen fuerzas con nueva tecnología y fondos para detener el fraude aduanero y fiscal y proteger los fondos públicos.
